column2: Ajahn Pasanno leads a discussion about the meaning and purpose of the Buddha's teachings on not-self.

column6: Session title

column3: 2015-06-27 Upasika Day The Middle Way of Not-Self.mp3
column6: The Middle Way of Not-Self

column3: 2015-06-27 Upasika Day The Purpose of Not-Self.mp3
column6: The Purpose of Not-Self
Text
What are the commentaries? How do they know stuff that isn't in the suttas?
What are mental formations and consciousness?
MN 44: Cūḷavedalla Sutta
The Buddha didn't answer the question, 'Is there a self?' But this question seems more important than other questions he didn't answer. How should we relate to not-self?
Are the skillful means for dealing with not-self aas easy as know and let go?
The question that occured to me was "If I take this as myself, where does it lead me?"
I've heard the teaching that if you watch your kilesas in samādhi, they tend to subside. Sometimes you watch your sakkāya-diṭṭhi and it's not going away. What to do?
Why go through all the trouble to teach us how to not have a self and then refuse to tell us there is no self?
regarding the intellectual framework of the aggregates versus bringing it back to experience.
Is renting a good metaphor for not-self?
We only rent this house. We don't own it.
"Our Real Home" in Collected Teachings p. 145
In regard to self and emotions, you acknowledge and embrace it but don't hold tightly?

In the classes I teach, we use the acronym R.A.I.N. – Recognize, Allow, Investigate, Not-identify. I explain not-identify by asking my students, "If you say, 'I am angry,' when anger goes away, what happens to you?"
The Buddha asks us to look at the things we identify with as self and notice they are not who we are. But if there's nothing else but those things, there is no self, right?
Isn't there then an implication that there is something else that could be self?
regarding not-self.
I've found it helpful to recognize that for me there aren't any right answers, only right questions.
Is the heir to my thoughts, words, and deeds me or some other guy?
The fear that arises upon the realization that there's nothing there is so strong that it takes away from the awareness being able to stay with it. Any suggestions?
With the analogy of the scent and the flower (SN 22.89), it sounds like it [the sense of self] is relational and there is an effect. But it gets tricky...
Does everything point back to the third satpaṭṭhāna (mindfulness of mind)?
Dhp 1

Ajahn Mun taught Ajahn Chah to distinguish between the mind and mind objects. Is the mind that distinguishes between these a development of ordinary mind or a larger mind that we tap into as we develop wisdom?
Both of these are wrong.
MN 11 Cūḷasīhanāda Sutta
about working with not-self in direct experience in relation to discomfort and awareness of embodied release.
I wanted to confirm that we're also not putting this self on other objects like the redness belonging to the rose.
It makes me suffer when those roses turn black and they're still on the shrine...which happens all the time!
Things change. But can't that be part of its nature that things change?
Could you say that attavādupādāna is that very trying to say 'Is it self or is to no self?'
Do you think it's enough to just be aware of the suffering that's caused by the clinging to self?
The most efficacious investigation comes from a still mind.
What you said reminds me of 'da resin.' [audio unclear]
"It's that sticky bit that creates the problems."

One of the things I often attend to is the juxtaposition of stillness and movement. It's not that one is right and the other wrong. We can be still and really dull or the mind can move with clarity and acuity. But stillness and movement, what's generating it, what's pushing it? That bhavadiṭṭhi/vibhavadiṭṭhi is the engine behind it and the force behing the arising of a sense of self, a sense of me.
Before I get to all that [deep reflection on not-self], in the meantime I thing of Luang Por Sumedho's saying, 'Every time I think of myself, I get depressed.'
It's difficult but it's not that complicated. The Buddha's teachings go against the grain of our conditioning and habits, but the essence of it is quite simple.
I notice how the mind defends suffering because it's so closely related to that idea of self. But if I let go of defending, what am I?
Is bhavadiṭṭhi the same word as cultivation (bhāvanā)?
